description: Designed by a famous Finnish architect, this modern building is home to the Toronto City Council.

reviews.title: ALMOST 60 YEARS LATER IT IS STILL FUTURISTIC
text: Opened in 1965, Finnish architect Viljo Revell did not live to see its completion. The council chamber is between the two towers. The building is a nice backdrop to pictures of Nathan Phillips Square.

reviews.title: A moving moment
text: They were setting up for an event for the holiday weekend & the theme was welcoming immigrants/understanding the immigrant experience which was beautiful. We had to leave the next day so missed it but saw some artwork being displayed & I found it familiar to my own experience as a refugee in 1975.

reviews.title: Impressive
text: The Old City Hall is a Romanesque-style civic building and former court house in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. It was the home of the Toronto City Council from 1899 to 1966 and a provincial court house until 2023, and remains one of the city's most prominent structures.Toronto's Old City Hall was one of the largest buildings in Toronto and the largest civic building in North America upon completion

reviews.title: Interesting, modern architectural design
text: The modern "new" City Hall is an attractive complex with an interesting architectural design - two curved towers around a central domed building, said to resemble a giant unblinking eye from above! It is free to enter the foyer of the complex and I would suggest you do, if only to view the Metropolis on the right side wall of the foyer area. It is an intriguing art piece fashioned from more than 100,000 nails!

reviews.title: Feel The Curve
text: Toronto City Hall is a pair of curved buildings. They are located on the Northern side of Nathan Phillips Square. On the Easter side is the old city hall which is an older building and more traditional design.
The city hall buildings are quite striking and I would love to have an opportunity to explore them but I guess you would have to work for the city to have this chance.

reviews.title: Better view at night
text: Water in summer, skate in winter in front of the city hall.
They held lots of festivals/markets through the year, with different food and  cultures to experience.
The light up at night us beautiful, highly recommended a visit.

reviews.title: Action packed in the Winter
text: When examined side by side with the old city hall, the new one does not look appealing to me. However, if you visit this place in the winter, you will see a variety of actions, such as ice skating and night market.

reviews.title: Great building
text: Dominating Nathan Phillips square this magnificent building and huge clock tower are a sight to behold.  The clock tower rings out the hour, not so good if you are in a local hotel!

reviews.title: What is this horrific concrete building?
text: OK.  I know you probably thought that the old city hall reeked of Colonist Oppressive Architecture - but that said its a beautiful impressive building.  What Canada has built instead is this horrific monstrosity with equally disgraceful concrete hotels suffocating what historic architecture was there.  What a shame.

reviews.title: Architecture a cool fountain and Toronto signage!
text: I find that this is rather underrated. If you love architecture this is a must see! There’s something really special about seeing the old buildings mixed in with modern ones. This building is particularly impressive, especially when the sunlight reflects off of the glass windows in the morning. It’s a cool place to take some great photos. Don’t forget about the fountain in front with the Toronto signage! Did I say cool pics? Um, yes. Definitely!

reviews.title: Landmark of Toronto
text: A symbol of Toronto.  The old City Hall building was at aside. If not in a hurry, can have a visit to the city hall.  There is a hourly car park three blocks away.  CAD15 for 2 hours.

reviews.title: STUNNING ARCHITECTURE
text: A nice place to stop off when visiting the amazing city of Toronto. Not only to take photos of the city's iconic name, but for admiring the stunning architecture all around.

reviews.title: Great backdrop
text: In our walk around town, we walked through this area.  Pretty nice place.  While we were there, they were having the Nuit Blanche one night.  So this area was turned into an interactive art display.  With dancing in the streets, Japanese Zen Garden, and a host of other artsy things throughout the city.  From 7 pm to 7 am.  Even had a Silent Disco in Graffiti Alley.  Absolute delight!

reviews.title: One of the symbols of Toronto
text: The result of a worldwide competition for its architect, the “new” city hall is a monument to its Finnish designer and an icon for the city of Toronto. Its unique design has two uneven curved office towers embracing an oyster-shaped domed council chamber raised above Nathan Phillips Square which is home to hundreds of celebrations, art shows and ice skating on the frozen reflecting pool. Designed to allow a space for the people of the city to gather and celebrate like the Raptors’ NBA win. Also a great place to stroll the length of the truck food vendors and breathe in the smell of freshly fried potatoes and poutine and the ever-popular street hot dog. Its New Years’ Eve party is not to be missed. It is famous for banning the group Barenaked Ladies which rather than harming the success of the group it gave it tons of free publicity and paved the way for its future success.

reviews.title: PHOTO OPPERTUNITY
text: Located outside city hall and is one of the tourist bus stops for a photo opportunity.  The Toronto Sign lights up at night and has a water feature in front which changes every so often.  Wasn't too busy when we visited but animal rights demonstrators waded in to the "pool" and chained themselves to a desk I think and had numerous banners.  Seemed there were demonstrations all over the place for all sorts of things.  Plenty of seating in the shade around two sides of the general location.  There were also ice cream and food trucks close by.

reviews.title: Toronto!
text: It's a good square to just laze around, walk by and take some pictures. It's flocked with tourists and always too busy.

reviews.title: Photo op
text: This was on our self guided tour from St. Lawrence Market to Kensington Market.  It was a good site for a photo op, but might not have gone out of our way to see it as a stand alone attraction.

reviews.title: City Hall
text: Great looking building in Downtown Toronto. Nice outdoor space as well. Good place to sit and people watch.

reviews.title: TORONTO Sign
text: Kind of cool if you are walking by - get a photo with the TORONTO sign - it lights up at night and changes colors.

reviews.title: Iconic Sign
text: Great area to bring food and people watch. Of course you gotta take a picture in front of the Toronto sign. We got there when there was still daylight and then the sign glows different colors (and changes) when it hits evening.

reviews.title: Walked all around here
text: It was beautiful here...lots of places to take photographs.  They have some tables and chairs to sit at if you want to grab a quick lunch.  There are food trucks at lunch time so you can grab a quick burger fries hot dog etc.  Loved the peace arches.

reviews.title: Iconic + Photogenic
text: A trip to Toronto would not be complete with a visit to the iconic architecture of the "new" City Hall.  Take selfies with the giant city sign!  and make sure to get the stately old City Hall into a picture, too.

reviews.title: One of the most famous places in Toronto
text: Toronto city landmark.  Located in the financial center of the city.  It was built in the early 1960s .One of the most famous works of the Finnish architect Vijo Revel. The two curved lumps rising in the city square are impressive. The futuristic looking Toronto City Hall is an iconic Toronto building almost as famous as the tower. Underground Municipal Parking available close by.

reviews.title: festive spectacle
text: great light show, square was very active with socially distanced skaters and kindness being shared by street workers to less fortunate

reviews.title: Modern architecture
text: Very famous building showing up in a lot of movies. Modern and nice architecture. Nice square with the ice skating ring.

reviews.title: Great styling used in Star Trek and other shows
text: Built in the 1960s this unusual looking building has featured in quite a few tv shows and movies.  It is a very functional building housing the City Council.

reviews.title: Just a wonderful building to view...especially at night
text: with the skating rink below and the changing lights of the building it is well worth the visit ....close to all the major attractions it is worth going for a walk to go and see the building.  There is an iconic Toronto sign and lots going on.  Between the street vendors, the food trucks, the city news reporter on sight and the skating rink it was worth it just to people watch....enjoy the city.

reviews.title: Enjoyable, but not much to do
text: The view of the city from the city hall is exceptional, and the iconic Toronto sign is right in front. However, we went when the sign was right in front of their ice skating rink, which made pictures with it difficult.

reviews.title: Iconic Toronto Sign
text: Every city has it's Icon and the 3D sign by Toronto City Hall is a must visit in Toronto. The sign is best viewed at night as it changes it's colors.

reviews.title: Beautiful City Views
text: A MUST when visiting Toronto...very beautiful and colorful. Very popular throughout the day, plenty of restaurants and shops nearby, public transportation close.

reviews.title: Interesting architecture
text: The old city hall here is quite a remarkable facade and it was nice to pause for  while to study it this afternoon.

reviews.title: Don’t bother as there are so many better Christmas markets
text: Currently at the City Hall area there is ‘Cavalcade of Lights’ which supposedly gives you the “magic of the holiday season”.
Now I will admit we arrived just before it became dark but OMG whoever organises this needs to visit Christmas markets in other countries because this market looks grim.
Unenthusiastic market stall holders, pathetic Christmas tree decorations, uninspired food.
Unfortunately there were several unwell homeless people gathering around the entrance which made the area seedy and unsafe.

reviews.title: Great views from the Sheraton Hotel
text: We were staying at the Sheraton and had great views of City Hall from our room. Quite a modern and unusual shaped building. Found in the square with the large Toronto city sign with lake and fountain. Popular spot with tourists and must be photographed with the sign.

reviews.title: Bloody awful
text: This city sucks. Traffic is unbearable to drive in to or out of this Toronto.

TTC is useless with ridiculous street cars. Subway system is very outdated for such a populated huge city. The city planners who are responsible for all the condominium builds need to be forced to drive around the noisy, dirty, mostly inaccessible city I've ever seen.
I've driven in all the major cities in North Americ.
Toronto wins for being the worst.
Just go somewhere else.

reviews.title: A wonderful day
text: Toronto, capital of the province of Ontario, is a major Canadian city located along the shores of Lake Ontario. Dynamic metropolis, it has a nucleus of soaring skyscrapers dominated by the iconic CN Tower.

reviews.title: Nice settings for pictures and selfie
text: Nice settings for pictures and selfies with the Toronto logo, and sometimes host festivals and markets. Close to the old city Hall.

reviews.title: Bustling place
text: We stayed at Sheraton right across from here for a week and everyday there was something happening in the park to see and do.

reviews.title: Toronto City Hall (inside) and Nathan Phillips Square (outside).
text: The City Hall is inside (space ship buildings) and Nathan Phillips Square is the whole area which includes outside with the fountain (ice rink in winter, I think, used to be anyway) and the seating are with good food trucks close by. Hasn’t changed much in the last 20+ years. Only the planing in city hall has (changed the city forever). What?! More Condos?! Ugh! Yep. But the area is nice for now. Go see it.

reviews.title: The City Hall Toronto sign - a good photo opportunity
text: I walked outside near Toronto City Hall and took a photo of the Toronto sign and the buildings.  It was a nice place to walk around outside.  Next time I want to come here in the evening when the sign and fountains are lit up.  The location is very good not far from the Eaton Centre.

reviews.title: Pleasure to stroll at night
text: Beautiful Toronto sign displayed in neon lights at night.A very Torontonian place to be.Close to Yonge St and Eaton Center.A landmark that has been around for almost 40 years that has become a  part of Toronto’s history.
